data.title: Add a way to choose theme variant (Gnome dark/light theme)
data.body:
Hello,

The default Gnome theme Adwaita come with 2 variants. One light and one dark. Each app that implement the feature, like Gnome terminal, allow you to choose the theme variant in the preference. It will be awesome if we can do this in Vs Code.

![screenshot from 2017-07-03 07-27-41](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17159065/27779206-bbb46458-5fc1-11e7-987c-57260b02ed8f.png)

![screenshot from 2017-07-03 07-28-14](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17159065/27779210-c1da4e10-5fc1-11e7-8cd1-f0161d14d16c.png)

![screenshot from 2017-07-03 07-27-23](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17159065/27779214-c95b88f2-5fc1-11e7-8287-2f45a7539417.png)

Thanks !

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.13.1 (379d2efb5539b09112c793d3d9a413017d736f89, 2017-06-14T18:21:47.485Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.15063
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|vscode-npm-script|eg2|0.2.0|
|flatbuffers|gaborv|0.1.0|
|Go|lukehoban|0.6.62|
|cpptools|ms-vscode|0.12.0|
|csharp|ms-vscode|1.11.0|
|vscode-icons|robertohuertasm|7.10.1|;


---

{
	"files.exclude": {
		"out": true,
		"debug": true,
		"typings": false
	},
	...
}

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Debug a Go project, have the debug file be generated next to the go file.
2. Try all of the variations found online for hiding a file called "debug"
3. Debug file remains in tree view, even after close/open and system restart.

data.title: And, or and not operators are treated like functions
data.body:
- VSCode Version: latest
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open a Lua file and use the syntax highlighting

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

The or, and, and not operators are not properly highlighted

http://i.imgur.com/VePdYJB.png

They are treated like functions.

I was directed here from the Lua support extension stating it is a VScode issue

data.title: 以前的bug 又重复出现了
调试以下代码时不会出现结果，使用node 直接运行可以出现正确结果
TS intellisense issues
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.14.0-insider (5cb4570007af28b5e0c0b4177e0283dc961ebbb8, 2017-06-30T22:27:13.873Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.5.0

---

Snippet like this in a TS file, using 2.4.1

```ts
import {ChildProcess} from 'child_process';

interface I1 {

}

class C1 {

}
```

- With the cursor on an empty line, press ctrl+space
- Type `C` - `C1` appears in suggestions ✔️ 
- `ChildProcess` doesn't appear in suggestions :bug:
- Type `I` - `I1` doesn't appear in the suggestions :bug:

So in some cases, interfaces don't appear but other types do. 

Maybe a separate issue,
- Add a line `let x: `, cursor set to enter the type annotation
- Press ctrl+space
- Suggest box is empty

data.title: Go to Definition and Go to Implementation Does not Work As Expected
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.13.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 Version 1703 Build 15063.413
- Node.js Version: 8.1.3

Steps to Reproduce:

1. `npm init`
2. `npm install --save bcrypt-nodejs`
3. use following code snippet what I use in recorded gifs:

```javascript
var bcrypt = require('bcrypt-nodejs')

UserSchema.pre('save', function(next) {
	var user = this
	if (!user.isModified('password')) {
		return next()
	}
	bcrypt.genSalt(10, function(err, salt) {
		if (err) {
			return next(err)
		}
		bcrypt.hash(user.password, salt, null, function(err, hash) {
			if (err) {
				return next(err)
			}
			user.password = hash
			next()
		})
	})
})
```

Reproduces without extensions: Yes

Issue: go to definition and go to implementation redirect me to `d.ts` files, not to implementation of method or function.

Gif VSCode (with issue demo):

![sublime-go-to-def gif](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20873402/27774345-75d635c8-5f45-11e7-9ea1-b17a3c8da345.gif)

Gif as expected (sublime as example):

![sublime-go-to-def gif](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20873402/27774301-b7ab0768-5f44-11e7-8c8f-dba2da46a861.gif)

This issue not present within the project i.e. with functions and methods what I Implemented myself. Simple example:

![vscode-issue-go-to-def gif](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20873402/27774648-bfd2586e-5f4a-11e7-9f42-760f25401a14.gif)

I also find this issue: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/19672 but it's closed for some reason. It's strange for me because I think "Go to Definition" and "Go to Implementation" is basic/must have feature in all IDEs.

Other related issues:

https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/25197
https://github.com/Microsoft/TypeScript/issues/9413
https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/8244

My VSCode config:

```json
// Place your settings in this file to overwrite the default settings
{
    "editor.fontSize": 17,
    "editor.fontFamily": "Hack",
    "editor.fontWeight": "100",
    "editor.tabSize": 4,
    "editor.cursorStyle": "line",
    "git.enabled": true,
    "explorer.openEditors.visible": 9,
    "explorer.enableDragAndDrop": true,
    "files.encoding": "utf8",
    "files.eol": "\r\n",
    "files.insertFinalNewline": true,
    "files.autoSave": "off",
    "window.openFilesInNewWindow": "default",
    "editor.renderWhitespace": "none",
    "window.zoomLevel": 0,
    "workbench.welcome.enabled": true,
    "editor.lineHeight": 24,
    "editor.fontLigatures": true,
    "terminal.integrated.shell.windows": "C:\\Windows\\sysnative\\bash.exe",
    "workbench.colorTheme": "Material Theme",
    "workbench.iconTheme": "eq-material-theme-icons",
    "editor.minimap.enabled": true,
    "editor.dragAndDrop": true,
    "editor.minimap.renderCharacters": false,
    "editor.cursorBlinking": "blink",
    "workbench.activityBar.visible": true,
    "workbench.statusBar.visible": true,
    "editor.mouseWheelZoom": false,
    "editor.renderIndentGuides": true,
    "editor.renderLineHighlight": "all",
    "editor.matchBrackets": false,
    "diffEditor.renderSideBySide": true,
    "editor.multiCursorModifier": "ctrlCmd",
    "extensions.autoUpdate": false,
    "editor.quickSuggestions": {
        "other": true,
        "comments": false,
        "strings": false
    },
    "subtleBrackets.disableNative": true,
    "subtleBrackets.parse": true,
    "subtleBrackets.styles": {
        "global": {
            "borderWidth": "1px",
            "borderStyle": "none none solid none",
            "borderColor": "#FFCC00"
        }
    },
    "editor.find.seedSearchStringFromSelection": true,
    "editor.find.autoFindInSelection": false,
    "editor.selectionHighlight": true,
    "editor.occurrencesHighlight": true
}
```

Installed Extensions:

[Subtle Match Brackets](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=rafamel.subtle-brackets) v.2.0.0
[Material Theme](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=Equinusocio.vsc-material-theme) v.1.0.0
[Beautify](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=HookyQR.beautify) v.1.1.1

data.title: Using the Find Widget (CTRL+f) adds padding/margin/something above first line of code
data.body:
So I noticed that whilst using the Find widget (CTRL+f), padding/margin/something is added above the first line of code.
![Issue in action](http://i.imgur.com/I44S4jz.png)

It seems to be about the same height as the find widget's height. So I'm guessing it's responsible. Actually if you close the widget the spacing disappears along with it.

Honestly, I don't even know if this is a bug.

- VSCode Version: 1.13.1
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open a file
2. Press CTRL+f
3. Scroll up (if you don't see a chasm above the first line of code), otherwise you should already be seeing it.

Reproduces without extensions: Yes

P.S. Sorry for adding another issue onto your issue list 😆

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.13.1 (379d2efb5539b09112c793d3d9a413017d736f89, 2017-06-14T18:13:05.928Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.6.0
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|vsc-material-theme|Equinusocio|1.0.0|
|vscode-simple-icons|LaurentTreguier|1.4.0|
|fish|TeddyDD|0.0.4|
|vscode-eslint|dbaeumer|1.2.11|
|python|donjayamanne|0.6.7|
|vscode-icon-theme|jtlowe|1.5.0|
|PowerShell|ms-vscode|1.4.1|
|sublime-keybindings|ms-vscode|2.9.0|
|Ruby|rebornix|0.12.1|
|trailing-spaces|shardulm94|0.2.11|
|theme-unoduetre|wavebeem|1.4.0|;

It would be very nice if the custom titlebars on Mac supported drawing a bottom border. I personally prefer the native titlebar along with my theme because this is missing, but considering the default setting is custom titlebars, it'd be good to be able to add one in so new users of my theme get a good experience.

data.title: CompletionItem.insertText broke in 1.13
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: Code 1.13.1 (379d2efb5539b09112c793d3d9a413017d736f89, 2017-06-14T18:18:03.540Z)
- OS Version: Linux x64 4.11.5-1-ARCH

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a extension providing completion items
2. return a suggestion with `{"textEdit": "a{{}}b"}`

In previous versions this inserted `ab` and placed the cursor between both characters but now it instead inserts `a{{}}b` and puts the cursor at the end of the input. I tried doing `new vscode.SnippetString("a{{}}b")` because in the documentation that is now added (I also needed to upgrade my vscode version inside the package.json) but that didn't change anything. It does work by creating a new SnippetString and then calling appendText and then appendPlaceholder and then appendText again but I'd rather not do that because it looks a lot more ugly than the old code and it would require a few changes that could possibly break in my extension.

And especially I wouldn't know how to change this line: `insertText = insertText.replace("{{}}", "{{stuff}}")`

data.title: Find in webview based views (html preview, release notes, extension editor)
data.body:
@mjbvz this PR replaces PR #22918 to address issue #2187.

I noticed that @Tyriar had essentially created a "simple find widget" to use in the terminal which was much simpler to reuse than trying to refactor the full "find widget".

I refactored that out into a reusable widget (SimpleFindWidget) and updated the terminal to use it (TerminalFindWidget).

I then created a WebviewFindWidget to be used by the webview to interact with the native webview find api. To respect the layering contract, I had to make the existing WebviewEditor into an abstract class and extend it in the correct layer so it could have access to the webview. HtmlPreviewPart and ReleaseNotesEditor now extend from that new WebviewEditor implementation and therefore both have access to the new find widget.

ExtensionEditor also now leverages the simple find widget to enable searching through readmes and release notes within the extension editor view.

Finally, I improved the styling of the simple find widget by adding "overflow: hidden" to the containers that use it so that it can properly be animated in.

**Caveat:** I don't know what HtmlEditorZone is so I didn't test that.

Here are gifs of it in action:

This is the find working in a markdown preview:
![simplefindpreview](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2957173/27770047-6675ea40-5f38-11e7-8c4b-91c7dc838865.gif)

This is the find working in release notes
![simplefindreleasenotes](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2957173/27770052-77ed4a34-5f38-11e7-8870-c2f1536df395.gif)

This is the find working the same as before in the terminal, but now with animation:
![simplefindterminal](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2957173/27770048-6ece6776-5f38-11e7-9a20-5ac36c0196f9.gif)

This is the find working in the webview sections of the ExtensionEditor
![simplefindextensions](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2957173/27770128-64df713c-5f39-11e7-8e77-bcdcdc328acd.gif)

data.title: Re-arranging folders order is not available in explorer panel
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.14.0
- OS Version: Windows 10

Re-arranging folders order is not available in explorer panel.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open new folder in vscode explorer. (File -> Open Folder)
2. Add another folder to workspace. (file -> Add Folder To Workspace...)

Folders order can't be changed unless removing the folders from workspace and adding them one-by-one in desired order.

data.title: Is there any way to get the css.colorDecorators to work with Less/Sass Variables recursively?
data.body:
Is there any way to get the css.colorDecorators square icons that represent the hex code colors to work with @import statements across files?  I currently have a "_colors.scss" file that I import into my master.scss for compiling.  The _colors.scss files shows all the icon colors as expected next to the hex codes, but in the master.scss if I use a color variable the icon to represent the color is not shown.

Example in _colors.scss
`$my-purple: (ICON SHOWS HERE) #332D7B;`

![screen shot 2017-07-02 at 8 47 04 am](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2436728/27769916-258a0abe-5f03-11e7-9246-31468ce2ab29.png)

Example in master.scss
```
@import 'colors';
#hd1 {background: (ICON IS MISSING) $my-purple;}
```

![screen shot 2017-07-02 at 8 47 29 am](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2436728/27769917-323a3428-5f03-11e7-8341-64199e4d5bb9.png)

Am I missing something or is there no way to display the icons recursively across files with Less/Sass Variables?

data.title: Typescript Automatic Type Acquisition cache update
data.body:
Typescript cache for typings (@types) is global and it is not automatically updated:
1. It would be great to have an option to update the typescript typings cache.
2. Updating typings cache can be achieved by deleting the content of @types folder and reload vs code - it should be considered mentioning in the documentations under ATA
3. In case a developer works on multiple projects with different versions of packages - Is there any better way other than manually and specifically install typings for each project?

data.title: Reformatting a document (such as auto-save during a debugger restart) results in breakpoints pointing to wrong locations
data.body:
Given the following code:

```dart
printThingInternal() {






  
  print('Hello, world!'); // Breakpoint on this line
}
```

When I reformat (or more subtly, when I hit `Restart` in a debugging session, which automatically saves, which fires format-on-save) the breakpoint ends up pointing at a totally different piece of code.

I believe the work in #10310 was to reduce the chances of things tied to source code being moved around in reformats so I wonder whether that should include breakpoints? In this case I believe Code is recalculating my edit as just a minor delete of some newlines, so in theory it has all of the information to preserve the breakpoint at the correct location?

data.title: Simulating a keypress for extensiona
data.body:
For the VSCodeVim extension, we are running into an issue where we are unable to handle tabs properly. When in insert mode, if the user presses tab, we must currently ignore it if the user presses tab, as we don't know what context the tab is done under.

The `<tab>` might be triggering an emmet abbreviation, it might be autocompleting, or it could just simply be a regular tab.

Is there any way to simulate a tab press (with all the associated context rules).

data.title: Integrated terminal doesn't autoscroll on select (Mac)
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.13.1
- OS Version: MacOS 10.12.5

**Steps to Reproduce:**

1. Issue some commands in the integrated terminal such that the output is partially scrolled out of view.
2. Click and drag to try to select more than what is visible.

**Expected behaviour:**

Scrolls up and continues to select.

**Actual behaviour:**

Selects the text below the initial select point.

data.title: Typescript Intellisense not working (using Angular4 project)
data.body:
I have set up an Angular project however TypeScript Intellisense is not working. Similar to #21630 (closed).


<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.13.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 (1703)

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Install Angular4: ```npm install -g @angular/cli```
2. Create Angular App: ```ng new my-app```
3. Initialise an array:   ```items = ["Angular 4", "React", "Underscore"];```

Edit: Additional steps
4. Typed ```this.items.``` but did not get Intellisense.
4. Typed ```items.``` but did not get Intellisense.


<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Edit: Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Debug stepping multi-threaded application doesn't follow thread
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.13.1
- OS Version: Fedora 21

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Place a breakpoint to interrupt execution.
2. Once the breakpoint is hit, step over (F10).

The focus in the call stack window will change from the current thread's call stack to the first call stack in the list. To continue stepping, the correct call stack (thread) must first be selected. 

This make stepping through threaded code quite tedious. 

The expected behaviour is that the focus in the call stack window remains at the top of the call stack for the current thread and doesn't change.

data.title: QuickFix should not target deeper than npm package root for import
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.13.1
- OS Version: win 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Reference a package that compiles to a folder deeper than the root. ex: `node_modules/package/dist/index.js`
2. Use an object from that package and quick fix import

The import points to the dist folder rather than the package root, even with a package.json `main` pointing to `./dist/index.js`

Changes to that packages folder structure would break these imports when pointing to the root would not.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: vscode on Windows 10 integratedTerminal
data.body: I have recently installed vscode in a Windows 10 VM as a guest on Ubuntu 17,04. Whenever I try to run any application with a setting of "console": "integratedTerminal",  PowerShell fails with an exception that '--' cannot be used in a powershell script blah blah blah. I have gotten around this by changing my intergatedTerminal to C:\\Windows\\sysnative\cmd.exe from the default. No big deal, but can anyone explain? I know that there people as anal as I.  If someone can explain, please do. -Jeff
